fields.Video Description: This video was recorded by Daniel KrauÃŸe on Vanua Lava Island in the Pacific Nation of Vanuatu, where Isso is one of the language's two remaining speakers. In the absence of government recognition or significant institutional support, Lemerig speakers have shifted to the neighboring Mwotlap and Vera'a languages in recent decades. However, the Vanuatu government's recent decision to incorporate local languages into public schools offers new opportunities for revitalization, should the community want it. Lemerig is an Austronesian language, sharing genealogy with over a thousand mother tongues, from Malagasy to Hawaiian.
YouTube License Statement: This video is licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution-ShareAlike 4.0 International license. To download a copy, please contact hello@wikitongues.org.
fields.Geneaology: "[ Austronesian, Malayo-Polynesian, Central-Eastern Malayo-Polynesian, Eastern Malayo-Polynesian, Oceanic, Central-Eastern Oceanic, Remote Oceanic, North and Central Vanuatu, Northeast Vanuatu-Banks Islands, East Vanuatu ]"

fields.Video Description: This video was recorded by Daniel KrauÃŸe on Vanua Lava Island in the Pacific Nation of Vanuatu, where Isso is one of the language's two remaining speakers. In the absence of government recognition or significant institutional support, Lemerig speakers have shifted to the neighboring Mwotlap and Vera'a languages in recent decades. However, the Vanuatu government's recent decision to incorporate local languages into public schools offers new opportunities for revitalization, should the community want it. Lemerig is an Austronesian language, sharing genealogy with over a thousand mother tongues, from Malagasy to Hawaiian.
